prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Juste output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text: One night two young men from Egulac went down to the river to hunt seals and while they were there it became foggy and calm. Then they heard war-cries, and they thought: 'Maybe this is a war-party'. They escaped to the shore, and hid behind a log. Now canoes came up, and they heard the noise of paddles, and saw one canoe coming up to them. There were five men in the canoe, and they said: 'What do you think? We wish to take you along. We are going up the river to make war on the people.' One of the young men said,'I have no arrows.' 'Arrows are in the canoe,' they said. 'I will not go along. I might be killed. My relatives do not know where I have gone. But you,' he said, turning to the other, 'may go with them.' So one of the young men went, but the other returned home. And the warriors went on up the river to a town on the other side of Kalama. The people came down to the water and they began to fight, and many were killed. But presently the young man heard one of the warriors say, 'Quick, let us go home: that Indian has been hit.' Now he thought: 'Oh, they are ghosts.' He did not feel sick, but they said he had been shot. So the canoes went back to Egulac and the young man went ashore to his house and made a fire. And he told everybody and said: 'Behold I accompanied the ghosts, and we went to fight. Many of our fellows were killed, and many of those who attacked us were killed. They said I was hit, and I did not feel sick.' He told it all, and then he became quiet. When the sun rose he fell down. Something black came out of his mouth. His face became contorted. The people jumped up and cried.He was dead.

Two evenings by the Wisconsin shore, two youths from Oshkosh ventured out to claimed seal hunting grounds. Yet as twilight deepened, a tranquil haze concealed the landscape. Amidst the silence, a fierce cry echoed through the mist. They suspected an imminent raid. Hastily escaping to the edge, they hid behind a colossal tree.

A flock of canoes appeared, gliding silently through the serene waters. Struggling to conceal their fear, they listened to the paddles crack against the still surface. An ominous number of six men filled the lead canoe, extending inviting hands. 'Join us,' they pleaded, their eyes gleamingunder the moonlight. 'We're embarking to the north to engage in battle against our enemies.'

Beside him, one youth hesitated, 'My provisions lack the vital arrows to ensure my continued existence amongst these brave warriors.' The other, however, succumbed to the pressure. 'I'll follow your lead,' he agreed. With a heavy heart, the first youth vanished into the night, leaving behind the battleground and the expectation of his loved ones.

Through the darkness, their canoes propelled towards the northern villages, trailed by a swell of anticipation and the whisper of potential glory. As dawn approached, the anticipation turned to bloodshed, each village street filled with combat cries and a spattering of cries.

They fought brutally, the blood of their enemies merging with their own, creating a synchronized symphony of despair. Growing weary, the young man from Oshkosh observed aghast as one of his comrades fell. His heart dropped; they'd lost. Despite his astounding escape and subsequent triumphs in battle, the warrior's cries shattered his thoughts.

'Quickly, we must return home.' The wounded warrior implored,, revealing signs of fatigue. Now the realizer agreed. His family welcomed the returning warrior, who happily shared tales of their recent successes against their enemies
